well done - at least the Executives in New York have been kind enough to say
Frances and Bo are leaving for home on the plane which will tarry
this letter but they will get off at Honolulu remaining there for a short
visit before proceeding to California.
They also plan to spend a little time
with my sister at Colorado Springs before going on to Ste Louis.
started out with the purpose of advising you that I have told the girls to
place their accounts - a very dubious favor - with you.
Am sure that they
will not need much help but will feel comfortable knowing that they can turn
to you tor aavices
I saw the pictures of the bombing of the Panay with one of my
friends who was on board - George Atchison - Second Secretary of Legation
who was my host at Nanking in November,
Of course I knew many of the victims
and used to often go on board the Panay at different points on the Yangstze -
especially when she was stationed at Ichang where our planes refueled thus
allowing enough time to take a cup of good American coffee with the hospitable
officers.
After drinking the English brand the merican was especially wel-
The net result of the Panay incident was the gaining of much "face
for imericans in the Far Baste
I believe the Japs are now convinced that
they were wrong when they thought there was an open season on.
am the very last one in the world who wants war with anyone but I believe
that imerican citizens who are engaged in the legitimate expansion of Amer-
ican trade are entitled to protection and respect whereever their business
takes them and so long as they live up to the standards of good citizenship
in the land of their temporary residences
I can not agree with certain of
our Congressmen who think that any American who turns his back on the Statue
of Liberty is a d -
fool who can be kicked around by any foreign power re-
gardless of treaties of
International agreements.
Personally I have seen
enough of modern war - truck loads of dismembered bodies staining the street
with blood - mothers carrying their dead children - little children torn and
mangled by ruthless bombing of unprotected noncombatants.
It seems that if
you do not want to raise your boy to be a soldier you had better see that no
one else does either.
The Chinese do not
seem to
neered and
as long as
their morale holds out there is always a chance for something to happen to
help their chances for a favorable peace.
I do not believe that the Japan-
ese will go broke - nations simply do not go broke during wars - aftervards
that is another matter.
There is a chance that the civil population may in
time revolt against the military if the Chinese can hold out long enough.
The present plan of the Chinese high command seems to be to encourage the
type of warfare with which the Chinese are most familiar and at which they
are most potent - i.e. guerilla tactics.
The Chinese never organize any-
thing and an army takes lots of organization.
Small groups of fifty or a
hundred men do not require much organization and the leaders are often men of
great ability who never fight unless the chances are highly favorable and it
is next to impossible to catch them if they decide to fight another day.
these chaps will keep the Japs busy holding on to the occupied territory
and thus prevent or long delay the conquest of more of
Our plans are as usual indefinite.
We shall probably remain
here in Baguio for a whihe and then unless something unexpected develops start
Hope to know within a week or two.
One of the few publications which all of us read out here is the
magazine TIlE, through which - though a bit late - we keep posted on what is
going on at home.
You no doubt read about Walter Weisenburger in a recent
issue and possibly noticed the reference to our mutual friend Clarence Francis
who used to be with Ralston and is now president of General Foods.
I do not
know whether or not his firm is doing any business with you but am sure he
would be glad to give his old friends in the State Bank a break if entirely
consistent.
Please give my very best to all of my friends in the li V. I.
especially Sid laestre, Lew Pumsey and Vill Pettus.
Pardon this long letter
and please keep it like others you have seen more or less confidential as I
certainly do not wish to be placed in the position of "experting" a situation
concerning which men of more ability and better sources of information are re-
luctant to write.
Dear 1. 0.
I am sending this in duplicate in case you may wish to forward the
original to Clarence Francis whose address is c/o Gen*1. Foods, 250 Park Ave.,
